verses.text: In the spring, when kings go out to battle, David sent Joab and his officers and all Israel, and they destroyed the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah. But David remained in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Kept literal timing ('spring, when kings go out'), as in the Hebrew, not smoothing into narrative.

verses.text: One evening, David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of the king’s house. From the roof he saw a woman bathing, and the woman was very beautiful in appearance.
verses.comment: Retained the phrase 'beautiful in appearance' (literally 'very good in appearance').

verses.text: And David sent and inquired about the woman. And one said, 'Is this not Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?'
verses.comment: Eliam and Uriah identified as in original. Used 'the Hittite' as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So David sent messengers and took her, and she came to him, and he slept with her. (Now she had been purifying herself from her uncleanness.) Then she returned to her house.
verses.comment: Added parenthetical as in the Hebrew; clarified ritual purification.

verses.text: The woman conceived, and she sent word and told David, 'I am pregnant.'
verses.comment: Kept word order and direct speech.

verses.text: So David sent word to Joab, 'Send me Uriah the Hittite.' And Joab sent Uriah to David.
verses.comment: Maintained direct order and precise names.

verses.text: When Uriah came to him, David asked how Joab was doing, how the people were doing, and how the war was going.
verses.comment: Kept David’s threefold inquiry as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Then David said to Uriah, 'Go down to your house and wash your feet.' So Uriah left the king’s house, and a gift from the king was sent after him.
verses.comment: ‘Wash your feet’ as euphemism for rest/refreshment, retained the literal sense.

verses.text: But Uriah slept at the entrance of the king’s house with all the servants of his lord, and did not go down to his house.
verses.comment: Kept word order; clarified location.

verses.text: When they told David, 'Uriah did not go down to his house,' David said to Uriah, 'Have you not come from a journey? Why did you not go down to your house?'
verses.comment: Direct questioning reflects original.

verses.text: Uriah said to David, 'The ark and Israel and Judah dwell in tents, and my master Joab and my lord’s servants are encamped in the open fields. Shall I then go to my house, to eat and to drink and to lie with my wife? As you live, and as your soul lives, I will not do this thing.'
verses.comment: Retained formal oath language and order: 'as you live, and as your soul lives.'

verses.text: Then David said to Uriah, 'Stay here today also, and tomorrow I will send you back.' So Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day and the next.
verses.comment: Faithful to verb forms and days.

verses.text: And David invited him, and he ate and drank in his presence and made him drunk. And in the evening he went out to sleep on his mat with the servants of his lord, but he did not go down to his house.
verses.comment: Kept ‘mat’ (Hebrew: 'bed') for clarity; specified continued refusal.

verses.text: In the morning, David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by the hand of Uriah.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; note Uriah carries his own death order.

verses.text: In the letter he wrote, 'Put Uriah in the front of the hardest fighting, and then draw back from him, so that he may be struck down and die.'
verses.comment: Kept 'hardest fighting' as literal translation ('strongest battle').

verses.text: So as Joab was besieging the city, he assigned Uriah to the place where he knew there were valiant men.
verses.comment: Kept 'valiant men' for clarity.

verses.text: Then the men of the city came out and fought against Joab, and some of the servants of David fell. Uriah the Hittite also died.
verses.comment: Retained sequence; 'servants' means soldiers.

verses.text: Then Joab sent and reported to David all the news concerning the war.
verses.comment: Literal rendering.

verses.text: And he instructed the messenger, 'When you have finished reporting all the news about the war to the king,
verses.comment: Joab’s instructions introduced as original.

verses.text: if the king’s anger rises and he says to you, ‘Why did you go so near to the city to fight? Did you not know they would shoot from the wall?
verses.comment: 'shoot' (literally 'strike'), context is archers.

verses.text: Who killed Abimelech son of Jerubbesheth? Did not a woman throw an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died at Thebez? Why did you go so near the wall?’ then you shall say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.’”
verses.comment: 'Jerubbesheth' = Gideon; kept 'upper millstone.'

verses.text: So the messenger went and came and told David all that Joab had sent him to say.
verses.comment: Literal rendering.

verses.text: The messenger said to David, 'The men gained an advantage over us and came out against us in the field, but we drove them back to the entrance of the gate.
verses.comment: 'Gained advantage' = 'prevailed over.'

verses.text: Then the archers shot at your servants from the wall, and some of the king’s servants died; and your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.'
verses.comment: 'Shot' as in context, literal is 'fired' or 'drew bows.'

verses.text: Then David said to the messenger, 'Thus shall you say to Joab: “Do not let this matter be evil in your eyes, for the sword devours one as well as another. Strengthen your attack against the city, and overthrow it.” And encourage him.'
verses.comment: Kept David's phrase, word for word as possible ('do not let this be evil in your eyes').

verses.text: When the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her husband was dead, she mourned for her husband.
verses.comment: Literal translation.

verses.text: When the mourning was over, David sent and brought her to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the LORD.
verses.comment: Kept formula 'the thing David had done was evil in the LORD’s eyes.'
